title: Which are the best organic chemistry books of the following authors: McCurry, Wade, Bruice, Carey, Vollhardt, Jones, David Klein, and Janice Smith? - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A It is very hard or impossible for me to judge which is the "best" book without having read them all. I would say it is often hard to judge which is the best of a series of books, people read books for different reasons. I keep a copy of Advanced Organic Chemistry by J. March in my office, this is the book I go to when I want to get advice on how to do a reaction, this book is very useful for the professional chemist but for a first year undergraduate it is unlikely to be useful as it is too advanced. Thus for me J. March is close to perfect while for a freashman it would be a poor choice of book. The freashman needs an introduction to the topic which explains the basic ideas to them in a way which they can learn from.

I am no big Chemist or something. Just a high schooler. But, the Way Janice Goryzinski Smith explains everything is very beautiful. You literally begin to love OC if you haven’t already. The problems too are of high level. I dont know much of other books though.
